comments.content: Catherine and Karen both recovered, but their experiences were worlds apart. Read more about their story here:  http://www.ucobserver.org/faith/2017/10/two_cancers/

Here in Norway we have a system similar to the one in Canada. Right now my mother is going through lung cancer treatment, and thankfully we don't have to worry about financing it ourselves. I pay my taxes with joy!

Everyone From the time they are born till the time that they die has medical coverage in Canada. Regardless of income, medical history, pre-existing conditions, the list goes on and on. State of the art, world renowned hospitals and dr's. That's us, CANADA!!!!!!!!

And she apparently had at least some insurance coverage. What would this do to someone without coverage? $450,000 of debt, IF YOU LIVE THROUGH IT. Unimaginable. Grotesque. For-profit insurance companies are nothing but vultures making a meal of human suffering. State-sanctioned mafia. It disgusts me that this country refuses to see this. Utterly obtuse and absurd.

The difference between a public service and a for-profit business. A Canadian gets health care, Americans get a giant bill consisting mostly of profit, and some average quality health care - if they haven't gone bankrupt.

I am also a breast cancer survivor, living in Vermont, but in a support network of survivors who live in the US and in Canada. What she described was pretty much the experience of my Canadian friends. I was in fact lucky. I had a very early stage which ... See More

I don't even know which emoji to use after watching this story.  I'm feeling all of them right now.  We thought we lived in the most progressive country in the world and we don't and its going backwards rapidly instead of forwards.  God bless these two women.   Thank you for sharing your story.
But its all about choices. In America, you can choose not to get cancer. In Canada cancer is forced upon you.

Im swedish  we have a similar system like Canada. But i guess even higher taxes. But still we have some of the worlds riches ppl living here. and not any poor ppl like in the states. So yes Bernie i hope the gun crazy ppl who voted on Trump will listen to what u have to say and go With the Democrats next time

My mother died from cancer 8 years ago this week. With all the medical treatments she went through for almost 2 years, as well as the in hospital hospice care the final week, my father told me the total costs of her care came to over $1.25M. Ridiculous.
USA is not the greatest country...great countries have health care for all....we have health insurance which is not care

I've received my own fair share of medical bills, and one aspect I find especially appalling is the 'negotiating' of the cost of services. As if human lives are items on Craigslist to be haggled over.

How is this possible and even allowable?  This is shameful that our government will allow these practices when it is proven that better, sustainable practices exist.  STOP with the excuses and just make it happen!!
The commoditization of health is a fundamentally sociopathic act.

I have commented many times of about the health care my family received in Quebec. Our interactions with five hospitals and lastly a hospice center has given me perhaps a personal and biased view of what it means to have universal health care. I have a ... See More
Wake up US! We are rich but unwilling to take thoughtful care of our people. So many of us have experienced the crushing costs of medical care so why don't we demand better? What are we scared of?

The ACA was never a real health plan. It was mostly just a law that made everyone buy insurance. Like how car insurance is mandated for all drivers. But at least the ACA got Americans looking at real health care. It's just the politicians who are stopping it now. Americans need different politicians.
I wake up every day thankful that I'm a Canadian  ❤

So you are saying that an 88 year old Canadian women isn't told over the phone( by some 20 year old making $10 an hour)that she can't get the drug her oncologist prescribed?  Oh, then it's way more fun here where one can aquire a major headache in no time at all while fighting for her elderly mother's right to live.
As of Jan. I will be paying over$5000 for a single Onocology visit. Fighting since 2001 breast cancer and lymphoma.

I wish this country would stop being so "stuck on stupid" regarding healthcare. I think greed causes people to be afraid of any shared system. If everyone gets care, they feel it will take from the quality of care they receive. I see it as defensive behavior from people who presume they will get less. Such primitive,selfish thinking!  😥

My Mom who has thankfully been going through treatment on Medicare has now hit the donut hole for prescriptions until the end of the year.  Although she has received good news her prescriptions are now out of pocket for her which thankfully she can pay ... See More

I am going through stage 4 stomach cancer treatment here in Canada. I could not conceive going through the stress of bills while undergoing the aggressive treatment. Certainly the Canadian system is imperfect but compared to the Gong show that is healthcare in the US it is amazing. I have no wait times and no double tier system despite what the Republicants are trying to tell their citizens. Wake up America.

"She was getting bills from people she'd never met for services she didn't really understand." That is American healthcare. I had an emergency c-section with my daughter. After, I got several bills with names of doctors I had never heard of. I just had to take the hospital's word that these people had actually seen and treated me in some way while I was unconscious.

I'm originally from the U.K. I was diagnosed with breast cancer while I still lived there. It was very similar to Canada. I found the lump and within 36 hours I had my diagnosis and treatment plan set up. I had chemo, mastectomy and radiation......no bills, no costs, I didn't have to pay for any medications or treatments. My healthcare was excellent and this year I am 10 years cancer free.

This was why my sister in law considered suicide when she discovered she had pancreatic cancer. Thankfully, I was able to talk to her to staying through treatment (she passed away a year later), it angers me to much we have to be stressed in our greatest time of need. It so goes against every thing we have been taught about from our core beliefs such as the golden rule and the Good Samaritan.
Maybe the ultimate goal should be providing information to us on how to emigrate to Canada. Sadly, I doubt our lives will ever be made better here in the US.
We need to do the same here and soon.  Enough of enriching the insurance companies.  God willing, next election?  If only people participate and demand it from their elected representatives.

You need to understand, the insurance negotiated the sisters bills down, but just their part, not hers. I know because on many of mine, they negotiate theirs down to UNDER what my co-payment of 15% is. So my 15% comes out to 120% per cent of the cost they actually pay.

I could not believe the stress I was put under with the threat of reporting me to the credit companies if I did not pay my bills on time. My copays for treatment were fully 50% of my SS earnings last year. I felt the pressure was unconscionable considering I had just been diagnosed with a life threatening disease. And I had to wait 10 days for treatment b/c my dr decided to leave for vacay a day early!

It’s the American Way to go bankrupt because of medical expenses. It’s also the American Way for 100 people to die because of gun violence. It is also the American Way for us to have a completely ridiculous electoral process with gerrymandering and the electoral college.
In Denmark we have a system similar to Canada and I pay my tax with joy knowing that if I, my family or any other Dane needs it we can go to the hospital and gået treatment for free 😊

As someone who is currently going thru this =="good" work coverage- i can tell you that the stress of dealing with insurance companies and the constant bills in the mail does not help. At all. And being told that the tx or in my case drug is not covered because it costs too much.....heartbreaking.
Sadly, until we get the pharmaceutical companies and insurance companies out of the political arena, we are screwed.  And it’s only gonna get worse.

As a home care RN with a patient population of almost all cancer patients, this outrages me on a daily basis. It’s time for the US citizens to stand up to big pharma and demand a single payer healthcare system with coverage for all. The  commercialization of healthcare is unconscionable!!

I also had Breast Cancer in Ontario, Canada. This is 100 percent true!!! There are no wait times, no payments or bills and excellent Health Care! I spoke to many Americans on Breast Cancer chat rooms that had to work while they were on Chemo and Rads to pay bills... keep fighting Americans for free Health Care!

I have been trying to explain this fundamental difference in quality of life to people here in California since moving here from Canada 23 years ago. Thanks for the great explanation.

Proud to be  🇨🇦 . As someone that wasn't born 'healthy' that has a chronic illness and depends on other people donating blood. I am so grateful that I am Canadian and feel for my US neighbours with the same illness.
This kind of thing will continue until we take over, and we aren't going to do that through their corrupt "elections".

I had cancer here in Canada....cost me 0.....not one cent....in under three weeks my cancer was discovered and I was operated on and home recuperating.   It's been 9 years with no recurrence so far, fingers crossed.   Watching the States makes me really thankful for our medical care system, as flawed as it may be.
